author: Abdalhadi_Fitouri
body:
Computer components companies are cyclical. When they release new products they boom. Otherwise they underperformed. 

Real investors understand this, so they never trade at as high a p/e as reddit expects. Reddit does this all the time. Like when they were obsessed with micron until Martin Shkreli wrote from prison that it seemed fairly valued because its a cyclical stock.

author: garrettd714
body:
TDOC, more like tele-don’t imo. Couldn’t sustain the biggest global catalyst they *hopefully* will ever have. Unprofitable, missing earnings, stock heading down since the vaxs and as you eluded to, now there’s more competition in space. I’m not even sure the boomers are into tele-health in any case, if they’re given an option. I was lured into this Covid play, just looking for an exit where I’m whole so, while I hope it trends up, I’m bearish. Probably will be a tax loss harvesting candidate EOY (-31.6%)

I like MU for a bounce

author: Amber_Rift
body:
20% is a fairly firm down #.  Theres really no telling how sharp a sell-off would be.  The sector leading the fall would also have to be considered and if it cascades to other stock sectors.  Your not the only one holding cash and waiting, I have a few positions in the red that are holds, and a few from 2010 that would have to fall %300+.
   After a pullback try and gauge the public sentiment.  If a bottom forms and its not a sharp recovery you should have a list of companies that have low price but good value(offer something people need) also help if it in something you know or use yourself.  Put a percentage in as a bottom forms and cost average from there on the recovery.
   At this point inflation on any dip in excess of 6 months would have to be brought into consideration.  The gov for sure would try some sort of rescue, unfortunately.   I did miss WM and F@$1 in 08 although it was on my radar fear of loss was a too strong swaying where i put mu money.

author: iopq
body:
$AMD P/E ratio is in the 30s and it's growing 99% a year. The industry projections show there's still a silicon shortage until 2023 so it will continue to improve ASPs and margins

I see no way for it to stay around $100 next year, since there are growth opportunities (quick growth in server) that would crash the P/E ratio to the teens if it stayed the same price

$INTC is already quite cheap, but it's continuing to grow

$MU is always crushing earnings

In terms of semis, everything minus $NVDA is cheap
I like $NFLX $MU and $ZM go erect this next days

author: joeabauer
body:
Before GME, everyone talked about large/mega cap names—FANGM, tsla, amd, nvda, mu, etc. Mostly spy.

There were some mid caps, but not like now with the 50 different teams of cheer leading lemurs.

I think there is a reason there is a <1 billion rule. Since the sub is now 20x larger, it should probably be <10 billion market cap…
